bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Luis B. Pogolotti, July 1, 1940

div1.p: Hench explains the reason for the confusion about the Camp Lazear site. Hench provides medical advice.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Luis B. Pogolotti, July 1, 1940
div1.opener:
Y. F.
July 1, 1940
Mr. Louis Pogolotti
Cuba 3
Habana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Pogolotti:
div1.p:
I am sorry indeed to hear that you never received two of my letters, and
particularly that the letter with all the photographs was lost. I must have sent
you twenty or so small photographs. I will get out the films within the next few
days and have another set printed for you. It gives me great pleasure to do this,
and I regret that you must have thought me very ungrateful for not writing you
sooner. I certainly did appreciate the wonderful you gave to me, and in due time
will send you my written report.

As I told you while in Havana, the last six or eight weeks were completely
filled with work, and only now am I able to get at the yellow fever work. I
visited a friend of Mr. Moran's, General Kean, in Washington and found out some
other information. Also at the Army Medical Museum, I found an old picture of
Camp Columbia with the railroad track and a small bridge across it at the site
of the false camp. On this site was a tent hospital where the volunteers who got
yellow fever at Camp Lazear on the San Jose farm were taken. That is the reason
that the confusion arose.

I really wish sometime that you would think seriously of coming up here, not
only to come to the Clinic, but if you ever come to America, I wish that you would
visit Rochester and be our house guest while going through the Clinic. I don't
believe the cold weather would worry you too much, certainly not if you came at
any time during the Summer, as it is as hot as the hinges of Hades here.

Have you ever tried taking the small capsules of ephedrin? You can get
this at any drug store, and I would suggest that you get the 25 mg. capsules.
You might try taking one or two every several hours, to see if this helps your
asthma.

I shall be delighted to hear from you at any time, and you will be hearing
again from me shortly.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
P.S. I sent the other letters addressed to you at Calle Cuba #3, Havana.
